metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Methods are functions that belongs to the class.
content.html: Methods are functions that belongs to the class.

content.text: There are two ways to define functions that belongs to a class:
content.html: There are two ways to define functions that belongs to a class:

content.text: Define a Method Inside the Class
In the following example, we define a function inside the class, and we name it " myMethod ".
content.html: In the following example, we define a function inside the class, and we name it "myMethod".

content.text: Note: You access methods just like you access attributes; by creating an object of the class and using the dot syntax ( . ):
content.html: Note: You access methods just like you access attributes; by creating an object of the class and using the dot syntax (.):

content.code_html:
class MyClass {        // The class
  public:              // Access specifier
    void myMethod() {  // Method/function defined inside the class
      cout << "Hello World!";
    }
};

int main() {
  MyClass myObj;     // Create an object of MyClass
  myObj.myMethod();  // Call the method
  return 0;
}

content.text: Define a Method Outside the Class
Sometimes it is better to declare the method in the class and define it later (especially in large programs).
content.html: Sometimes it is better to declare the method in the class and define it later (especially in large programs).

content.text: This is done by specifiying the name of the class, followed the scope resolution :: operator, followed by the name of the function:
content.html: This is done by specifiying the name of the class, followed the scope resolution :: operator, followed by the name of the function:

content.code_html:
class MyClass {        // The class
  public:              // Access specifier
    void myMethod();   // Method/function declaration
};

// Method/function definition outside the class
void MyClass::myMethod() {
  cout << "Hello World!";
}

int main() {
  MyClass myObj;     // Create an object of MyClass
  myObj.myMethod();  // Call the method
  return 0;
}

content.text: You can also pass values to methods just like regular functions:
content.html: You can also pass values to methods just like regular functions:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// 
  Call the method with an argument

syntax_highlighting.text:
// 
  Call the method with an argument

content.code_html:
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

class Car {
  public:
    int speed(int maxSpeed);
};

int Car::speed(int maxSpeed) {
  return maxSpeed;
}

int main() {
  Car myObj; // Create an object of Car
  cout << myObj.speed(200); // Call the method with an argument
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// 
  Call the method with an argument

content.text: Create a class Dog with a method bark() that prints "Woof!" .
content.html: Create a class Dog with a method bark() that prints "Woof!".

content.text: Then call that method from main() using an object of the class.
content.html: Then call that method from main() using an object of the class.

content.code_html:
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

class Dog {
  public:
    void bark() {
      cout << "Woof!";
    }
};

int main() {
  Dog myDog;
  myDog.bark();
  return 0;
}

content.html: How can methods be defined in a C++ class?
